definitions.definition: to move something into a particular place or position

examples.text: Put the cases down there, please.
Did you put sugar in my coffee?
Put your hand up if you need more paper.

definitions.definition: to move something into a particular place or position using force

examples.text: He put his fist through a glass door.

definitions.definition: to cause somebody/something to go to a particular place

examples.text: Her family put her into a nursing home.
It was the year the Americans put a man on the moon.

definitions.definition: to attach or fix something to something else

examples.text: We had to put new locks on all the doors.
We're not allowed to put posters on the walls.
Can you help me put the roof rack on the car?

definitions.definition: to write something or make a mark on something

examples.text: Put your name here.
Friday at 11? I'll put it in my diary.
I couldn't read what she had put.

definitions.definition: to bring somebody/something into the state or condition mentioned

examples.text: I was put in charge of the office.
The incident put her in a bad mood.
**Put yourself in my position**. What would you have done?
I tried to **put the matter into perspective**.
Don't go **putting yourself at risk**.
I am determined to **put things right**.
It was time to **put** their suggestion **into practice**.
This new injury will **put him out of action** for several weeks.
He put Ray on guard with a gun.

definitions.definition: to make somebody/something feel something or be affected by something

examples.text: Her new job has put a great strain on her.
They **put pressure on** her to resign.
It's time you **put a stop to** this childish behaviour.

definitions.definition: to express or state something in a particular way

examples.text: She put it very tactfully.
**Put simply**, we accept their offer or go bankrupt.
**Simply put**, the film is a masterpiece.
I was, **to put it mildly**, annoyed *(= I was extremely angry)*.
**Putting it bluntly**, the project was a disaster.
He was too trusting—or, **to put it another way**, he had no head for business.
The meat was—**how shall I put it?**—a little overdone.
As T.S. Eliot puts it…
She had never tried to **put** this feeling **into words**.
Can you help me put this letter into good English, please?
I thought you put your points very well.

definitions.definition: to give or attach a particular level of importance, trust, value, etc. to something

examples.text: Our company puts the emphasis on quality.
He put a limit on the amount we could spend.

definitions.definition: to consider somebody/something to belong to the class or level mentioned

examples.text: I'd put her in the top rank of modern novelists.

definitions.definition: used to say that you think somebody is capable of doing something wrong, illegal, etc.
to suggest something to somebody to see if they can argue against it

examples.text: I put it to you that you are the only person who had a motive for the crime.

definitions.definition: to persuade somebody to believe something that is not true

examples.text: Don't try to put one over on me!

definitions.definition: to force somebody to experience something difficult or unpleasant

examples.text: They really put me through it *(= asked me difficult questions)* at the interview.

definitions.definition: used when comparing or contrasting somebody/something with a group of other people or things to mean ‘combined’ or ‘in total’

examples.text: Your department spent more last year than all the others put together.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody to stop just talking about something and actually do it, show it, etc.

wordOrigin: Old English (recorded only in the verbal noun putung), of unknown origin; compare with dialect pote ‘to push, thrust’ (an early sense of the verb put).
